title: Hong Kong police say the shooting of a student protester was 'reasonable and lawful'
text:
Advertisement

Hong Kong police have defended an officer's decision to shoot a teenager during a clash yesterday, calling the act 'reasonable and lawful'.

Police said the officer's life was in great danger when he opened fire at point-blank range in Tsuen Wan district, wounding the 18-year-old who is a student.

Tsang Chi-kin, 18, was shot in the chest with a live round by a policeman as he was hit by the teenager with a metal pole, as a video shows. Surgeon removed the bullet from the teen and he was in stable condition in hospital on Wednesday.

Police Commissioner Stephen Lo said the officer had feared for his life and made 'a split-second' decision to fire a single shot at close range.

'When officers' lives are under threat, [they] can use reasonable force,' said Deputy Commissioner of Police Tang Ping-keung at a press conference today.

Thousands of office workers gather at the Central business district in Hong Kong on Wednesday to denounce police shooting of a teenage protester during widespread anti-government demonstrations that marred China's National Day on October 1

Protesters on Wednesday gather outside the entrance of the West Kowloon Court in Hong Kong where some 96 protesters arrested and charged with rioting during clashes with police on September 29 were to make an appearance in court

'His [the officer's] life was hanging on a thin line and there was no other choice to use other types of force or other types of weapons,' Mr Tang added.

He said the officer had fired at his chest to immobilise the youth quickly.

Mr Tang denied that police had been given permission to shoot to kill. He said the officer's action was in line with international procedures, but that police would mount an in-depth investigation.

Hong Kong's government said the widespread rioting on Tuesday was 'planned and organised' and called on parents and teachers to help restrain young protesters.

China's state media has defended the police shooting as 'totally legal and appropriate'. In a commentary today, state news agency Xinhua once again blamed the city's unrest on unidentified 'manipulators'.

Hong Kong office workers and high-school students today turned out in their hundreds under a sweltering midday sun to denounce the police officer's act during the most violent clashes in nearly four months of unrest.

The office workers gathered in Chater Garden in the Central business district as the students - some in the same class as the wounded 18-year-old - demonstrated outside his school in New Territories.

Demonstrators have been urging for an independent inquiry into what they view as excessive violence from the police since June when the unrest first broke out. The city's leader has refused to meet the demand.

One protester holds a signboard that reads 'disband the police force now' outside the West Kowloon Court on Wednesday

A woman holds up her phone showing an image of a policeman shooting another man at a rally at the West Kowloon Court

Schoolmates of form five student Tsang Chi-kin, 18, place their hands on their chests during a protest at a school in Hong Kong on Wednesday. Tsang was shot in the chest by police during violent protests that coincided with China's National Day

Throngs of anti-government protesters march at Central district in Hong Kong to voice their anger at police on Wednesday

Students raise their arm as they take part in a march accusing the police of using excessive force in Hong Kong on Wednesday

More than 100 people were wounded during yesterday's turmoil, the Hospital Authority said, as anti-China demonstrators took to the streets across the Chinese-ruled territory, throwing petrol bombs and attacking police who responded with tear gas and water cannon.

Police made 269 arrests, including 179 men and 91 women aged between 12 and 71.

Officers yesterday fired six live bullets in four separate incidents, some 1,400 rounds of tear gas, 900 rubber bullets, 190 rounds of bean bag and 230 sponge grenades. They also used water cannon trucks to disperse protesters.

Protesters outside the wounded student's school, the Tsuen Wan Public Ho Chuen Yiu Memorial College, chanted 'Free Hong Kong', condemned the police and urged a thorough investigation.

'(It's) ridiculous, it can't happen, and it should not be happening in Hong Kong,' said one 17-year-old who goes to the same school.

'It really disappointed me and let me down about the policeman. I don't know why they took this action to deal with a Form Five student. Why do you need to shoot? It's a real gun.'

Social media footage captures the moment Tsang (left) was shot by a policeman during a fight in Tsuen Wan on Tuesday

The teen was shot in the chest by a police officer whose unit had been attacked by demonstrators, said a police spokesperson

Anti-government protesters are detained by riot police during a demonstration in Wong Tai Sin on China's National Day

Motorbikes are on fire after they were hit with a Molotov Cocktail during a protest in Wong Tai Sin on Tuesday

Demonstrators in Central chanted slogans including 'five demands not one less' and sang their unofficial anthem 'Glory to Hong Kong'.

They also read out a statement together.

Part of the statement read: 'Police confounded black and white for yesterday's shooting incident.'

It also said: 'We have wisdom and conscience and won't accept government lies and police rule. '

Crowds also gathered outside the West Kowloon Court to voice their anger at police. Some were calling the forces to be disbanded.

Ninety-six people, who had been arrested and charged with rioting in relation to clashes with police during rallies on September 29, were to make an appearance in the court today.

Protesters have previously been hit with anti-riot bean-bags rounds and rubber bullets and officers have fired live rounds in the air, but this was the first time a demonstrator had been shot with a live round.

Police said the officer involved was under serious threat and acted in self-defence in accordance with official guidelines.

Students show their solidarity with the wounded 18-year-old who was the first person to be shot by police in the unrest

A protester holds up artwork on a placard depicting Tsang being shot in the chest by police during rallies on Tuesday

A schoolmate of Tsang holds a placard that reads 'police mistreat and murder residents' during a protest on Wednesday

A demonstrators place their hand on the chest to show their solidarity during an anti-police demonstration on Wednesday

Students raise their hands and cover their eyes during a rally on Wednesday in reference to other protesters who were hurt

A spokesperson said the officer fired at Tsang because he feared for his life.

'In this very short span of time, he made a decision and shot the assailant,' police chief Stephen Lo said.

But protest groups said the officer charged into the melee with his firearm drawn and condemned the increasing use of live rounds.

'The people of Hong Kong are sick and tired of having mere words of condemnation as their only shields against lethal bullets and rifles,' a masked protester said at a press conference near Tsang's school.

Wounded student Tsang is seen being taken to hospital by paramedics after being shot in the chest by police on the street

A handout picture shows the injured activist being given first aid before being taken to Princess Margaret Hospital

Students hold a sit-in outside the secondary school where Tsang studies after the student was shot during demonstrations

According to hospital authorities Tsang is in a stable condition after being shot by a police officer yesterday

Demonstrators complain that the officer approached Tsang with his weapon drawn before he opened fire

Tuesday's protests, on the 70th anniversary of the founding of the People's Republic of China, were aimed at propelling the activists' fight for greater democracy onto the international stage and embarrassing the city's political leaders in Beijing.

The former British colony has been rocked by months of protests over a now-withdrawn extradition bill that would have allowed people to be sent to mainland China for trial but have evolved into calls for democracy.

The outpouring of opposition to the Beijing-backed government has plunged the city into its biggest political crisis in decades and poses the gravest popular challenge to President Xi Jinping since he came to power.

Hong Kong is ruled under the 'one country, two system' policy and has different legal and governing systems to mainland China. The principle was agreed on by China and the UK before the former British colony reverted to Chinese rule in 1997.

However, many residents in the semi-autonomous city feel that their freedoms are eroding due to the tight political grip of Beijing.

The extradition bill was suspended indefinitely by the government in June, but the rallies have morphed into a wider pro-democracy movement that calls for government reforms and universal suffrage, among others.

Protesters are also demanding an independent inquiry into what they view as excessive violence from the police during clashes.

An anti-government protester is detained by riot police during a demonstration on China's National Day in Wong Tai Sin

An anti-government protester stops to read a graffitti during a protest on China's National Day in Hong Kong

A black-clad protester walks past flames rising from a fire in Hong Kong after the city witnessed a day of blood and violence

A riot policeman detains an anti-government protester during demonstrations on China's National Day on Tuesday

Police charge towards protesters in Wan Chai. Protesters were filmed throwing eggs at President Xi's portrait in the are

The pro-establishment Democratic Alliance for the Betterment and Progress of Hong Kong condemned Tuesday's violence and urged the government to impose emergency laws to resolve the crisis.

Many shops and business closed on Tuesday in anticipation of the violence, which is taking a growing toll on the city's economy as it faces its first recession in a decade and the central government grapples with a U.S.-China trade war and a global slowdown.

Standard & Poor's cut its Hong Kong economic growth forecast on Tuesday to 0.2 per cent for this year, down from its forecast of 2.2 percent in July, blaming tension in the city for plunging retail sales and a sharp dip in tourism.

The Hong Kong General Chamber of Commerce condemned the violence.

'Extremists' chilling disregard for the rule of law is not only affecting Hong Kong´s reputation as an international financial and business centre, but also crippling many small businesses and threatening the livelihoods of hundreds of thousands of ordinary citizens,' it said in a statement.

Social media footage shows protesters pelting a portrait of China's President Xi Jinping with eggs in Hong Kong on Tuesday

A fire lit by protesters burn in the Sha Tin district of Hong Kong as violent demonstrations take place in the streets of the city

People take part in a march in the Causeway Bay in Hong Kong on Tuesday as the city defies Beijing's National Day festivities

A riot police officer points his projectile launcher as his colleagues detain demonstrators in the Sha Tin district of Hong Kong

Police detain demonstrators in the Sha Tin district of Hong Kong after the city was turned into battlefields due to unrest

While the rest of China is celebrating the 70th anniversary of the Communist regime, Hong Kong has been plunged into chaos

The protesters come from wide-ranging backgrounds. Of 96 charged after violence on Sunday, eight were under 18, some were students, others had jobs ranging from waiter, teacher and surveyor to sales manager, construction worker and a hotel employee.

Protesters are angry about what they see as creeping interference by Beijing in their city's affairs despite a promise of autonomy in the 'one country, two systems' formula under which Hong Kong returned to China in 1997.

China dismisses accusations it is meddling and has accused foreign governments, including the United States and Britain, of stirring up anti-China sentiment.

The protesters are increasingly focusing their anger on mainland Chinese businesses and those with pro-Beijing links, daubing graffiti on store fronts and vandalising outlets in the heart of the financial centre.

The Bank of China (Hong Kong) said two of its branches came under attack on Tuesday.

'The bank expresses its deepest anger and strongly condemns this illegal, violent behaviour,' it said in a statement.
description: Hong Kong police have defended an officer's decision to shoot a teenager during a clash yesterday, calling the act 'reasonable and lawful'. Police said the officer's life was in great danger.
